I just don't take the stories that seriously, though they were fun.
 
 However, I believe that the series was particularly popular in the gay community. I base this on the prominence of the books in Outwrite, one of the gay bookstores in Atlanta, when the series was still young. They don't have room for everything in gay bookstores, especially not for ostensibly straight literature, but they did have room for Harry Potter, and not at discount prices, either.
 
 If I'm right, it's probably not too difficult to guess why: wizards were secretive, magical creatures in a prosaic Muggle world that was afraid of and despised magic. They had to conceal themselves, and lead semi-secret lives in order to be left in peace. Many gays probably see themselves in a similar light with themselves as creating a special world that's a little out of the ordinary compared to the dull, quotidian straight world they are forced to hide from. Gays, like Rowling's wizards, have to assume protective coloration to avoid harassment. Gays, like wizards, have ways of knowing each other that straights and Muggles aren't aware of -- a glance here, a knowing, arch look there.
 
 I see no reason to think that Rowling had deliberately intended such parallels, and frankly I strongly doubt she ever did (or does now) consider the series to have any sort of gay theme. Not even Dumbledore, who never struck me as remotely sexual at all. Maybe she's pandering, who knows? But there are clear resonances obvious to anyone who has lived in the gay demi-monde.

 This is true -- I occasionally reread LOTR, and there are lyrical sections I skip from sheer boredom. Well, it is a vast tome and you can't expect the author to feed a constant interest for everyone for that many pages. And there are undoubtedly famous authors even more unreadable than Tolkien -- I could name a few!
 
 Still, one can't take from Tolkien the fact that he was a pioneer of sorts and created a world of Homeric proportions. Whether Rowling's is as great an achievement or pales in comparison is probably not something worth shedding blood over -- it is on a less grandiose scale, granted, and it is primarily for children, whereas Tolkien was writing principally (I think, anyway) for adults.
 
 But irrespective of their individual achievement, Tolkien, Lewis and Rowling are inevitably going to be compared because there is little epic work in that genre that makes it out of the science fiction and fantasy coterie.

Another interesting take on Gay Dumbledore story:
 
 Is Dumbledore Gay? Depends on Definitions of 'Is' and 'Gay'
 
 From the conclusion:
 
 
[Rowling's] heroes are the hybrids, the misfits, those of mixed blood, all bearing scars of loss and love: the half-giant Hagrid, the mudblood Hermione (whose parents were not wizards), the poverty-stricken Ron, the orphaned Harry. Perhaps speaking of Dumbledore as gay was just a matter of creating another diverse rebel against orthodoxy.
 
 This is the formula for much popular fiction, but Ms. Rowling refuses to be content with simply rejecting the old order and championing a morally vague multiculturalism. The pure-bloods here are blinded by their pride, but Harry and his friends see something more profound, a threat that goes beyond self-interest and identity. This is why Dumbledore's supposed gayness is ultimately as unimportant as Ron's shabby clothes. These wounded outsiders recognize the nature of evil, and finally that is what matters.

 
 I have to agree. What is important is not whether the fictional Dumbledore was gay (or even sexual!), or even that Rowling decided to retrofit him with gay apparel -- I don't seriously imagine that anyone reading the books is ever going to have an Aha! moment and say unprompted, "Of course! Albus is gay as a goose!" It's the championing of the misfit and the unorthodox against tradition, convention and conformity. 
 
 Of course, many people (perhaps most?) see themselves as misfits at least on occasion. Some with more justice than others. Mix that common thread in with the immortal battle of good and evil and you get a heady and popular cocktail.
